awd_titl_txt: Analyzing the Tropical Impact of a Subpolar Thermohaline Anomaly
awd_abstract_narration:
0095057/Curry

In the late 1980s and early 1990s the source of Labrador Sea Water (LSW) 
became colder, fresher and denser during a persistent high phase of the 
North Atlantic Oscillation.  This provided an anomalous signature which 
could be used to track deep water as it flows south in the Deep Western 
Boundary Current (DWBC) of the North Atlantic.  This project will 
analyze data collected from a series of sections across the deep western 
boundary current in and near the tropical Atlantic, including some that 
were recently made under a Small Grant for Exploratory Research.  One 
aim is to determine the speed with which the anomalous LSW signal is 
traveling along the western boundary of the North Atlantic.  This will 
provide an estimate of how rapidly climate signals associated with 
adjustments in the ocean's meridional overturning circulation can 
propagate from high to low latitudes.  This is an important parameter 
in many scenarios of climate change and one that can be used to test 
the fidelity of climate models.  A second aim is to determine the 
dynamical effects on the DWBC of the passage of this anomalously low 
potential vorticity.
